docs.title: Water Quantity and Quality Monitoring Platform
docs.text: A decision-support platform for near real-time monitoring of water surface area and quality in South Africa using remote sensing and in-situ data.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
Water resources are under threat due to climate change, pollution, and increased demand. This project provides a robust, scalable solution to track water quality and quantity over time using satellite data (Sentinel-2, Landsat), geospatial processing, and modern backend frameworks like Django and Celery.

The platform features: - Automatic and semi-automatic monthly water quality and quantity mapping - Time-series analytics and forecasting of eutrophication spread - Downloadable raster outputs, web map views, and structured reports

docs.title: Key Concepts
docs.text:
A project represents a specific water body or region being monitored.

Context layers provide essential geospatial context such as administrative boundaries, land cover, or rainfall.

Indicators are derived from satellite indices like: - AWEI (Automated Water Extraction Index) - NDTI (Normalized Difference Turbidity Index) - NDCI (Normalized Difference Chlorophyll Index) - SABI (Surface Algal Bloom Index)

docs.title: Disclaimer
docs.text: This platform is intended for environmental monitoring and decision support. Users must independently verify all information before acting. SANSA and contributors are not liable for any adverse outcomes resulting from use of the platform.

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text: To support evidence-based decisions around water resources through automated monitoring tools and EO-based analytics.

docs.title: Scope of Project
docs.text:
• Monthly index computation (AWEI, NDTI, NDCI, SABI)
  • Integration of in-situ and satellite data
  • API access to analysis results
  • Report generation in PDF and TIFF formats
  • Dockerized deployment with cloud support

docs.title: Description of The Admin Sidebar
docs.text:
1. Filter, to search left sidebar.
  2. Sidebar menu, click to show the record.
  3. Toggle hide/show sidebar

docs.title: Add Crawler
docs.text:
1. Select Crawlers on th left sidebar.
  1. On the right sidebar, click ADD CRAWLER.
  1. Fill the Name, Description, Province, Image Type, and Resolution. Bbox will be populated automatically from selected Province.
  1. Click Save at the bottom of the page

docs.title: Run Periodic Task
docs.text: Periodic task has been set to run automatically on the 1st date every month. It will process data from previous month. Example: Periodic task that runs on March 1st 2025 will process data from February 2025.

docs.title: Run All Crawler
docs.text:
Follow these steps to run periodic task manually: 1. Go to Periodic tasks menu on the left sidebar. You can also search it.

  1. Click on the checkbox to the left of update_stored_data_monthly.
  2. On the Action dropdown, select Run selected tasks.
  3. Click Go.

5. A success message should be shown.

docs.title: Run selected crawler
docs.text:
Follow these steps to run periodic task manually: 1. Go to Crawlers menu on the left sidebar. You can also search it. 2. Select the Crawlers that you want to run. 3. Click dropdown, select Run crawler for last month. 4. Click Go

  1. Success essage should be shown

docs.title: Show Crawler Progress
docs.text:
1. Go to Crawl progresses menu on the left sidebar. You can also search it.

  2. You can see the progress

docs.title: Checking Task Logs
docs.text: 1. Go to Task logs menu on the left sidebar. You can also search it.

docs.title: Using Admin Page
docs.text: Go to Task outputs menu on the left sidebar. You can also search it.

docs.title: Using API
docs.text:
Make request to this URL to get paginated results of Task Outputs.

http://10.150.16.178:8888/api/task-outputs/

You can also filter the results by monitoring_type__name, from_date, to_date, bbox, page, and page_size.

http://10.150.16.178:8888/api/task-outputs/?monitoring_type__name=AWEI&from_date=2025-03-01&to_date=2025-03-31&bbox=18.8710767506562824,-33.8205932191388783,18.8736486550678428,-33.8184169923290980&page=1&page_size=10&page_size=100&page=1

It will give you AWEI output between March 1st 2025 to March 31st 2025, for the specified bbox, with 100 records on each page, and show records on page 1 (if there are multiple pages of the result).

docs.title: Contributing to Water Quantity and Quality Monitoring Platform
docs.text:
First off, thanks for taking the time to contribute! 🎉 😘 ✨

The following is a set of guidelines for contributing to this project. These are mostly guidelines, not rules. Use your best judgment, and feel free to propose changes to this document in a pull request.

docs.title: Reporting bugs
docs.text:
Bugs are tracked as GitHub issues. Search the list and try reproduce on your local machine with a clean profile before you create an issue. When you create an issue, please provide the following information by filling in the template.

Explain the problem and include additional details to help maintainers reproduce the problem:

  • Use a clear and descriptive title for the issue to identify the problem.
  • Describe the exact steps which reproduce the problem in as many details as possible. Don't just say what you did, but explain how you did it. For example, if you moved the cursor to the end of a line, explain if you used a mouse or a keyboard.
  • Provide specific examples to demonstrate the steps. Include links to files or GitHub projects, or copy/paste-able snippets, which you use in those examples. If you're providing snippets on the issue, use Markdown code blocks.
  • Describe the behaviour you observed after following the steps and point out what exactly is the problem with that behaviour.
  • Explain which behaviour you expected to see instead and why.
  • Include screenshots and animated GIFs which show you following the described steps and clearly demonstrate the problem.

docs.title: Suggesting enhancements
docs.text:
In case you want to suggest an enhancement, please follow this guideline to help maintainers and the community understand your suggestion. Before creating suggestions, please check issue list if there's already a request.

Create an issue and provide the following information:

  • Use a clear and descriptive title for the issue to identify the suggestion.
  • Provide a step-by-step description of the suggested enhancement in as many details as possible.
  • Provide specific examples to demonstrate the steps. Include copy/paste-able snippets which you use in those examples, as Markdown code blocks.
  • Include screenshots and animated GIFs which helps demonstrate the steps or point out the part of project which the suggestion is related to.
  • Explain why this enhancement would be useful to most users.
  • List some other text editors or applications where this enhancement exists.

docs.title: First code contribution
docs.text:
Unsure where to begin contributing? You can start by looking through these document, good first issue and help wanted issues:

  • document issues: issues which should be reviewed or improved.
  • good first issues: issues which should only require a few lines of code, and a test or two.
  • help wanted issues: issues which should be a bit more involved than beginner issues.

docs.title: Development workflow
docs.text:
• Set up your development environment
  • Make change from a right branch
  • Be sure the code passes tests
  • Make a pull request

docs.title: Development environment
docs.text:
• Prepare your machine and it's packages installed.
  • Checkout our repository
  • Install dependencies by pip install -r REQUIREMENTS-dev.txt

docs.title: Checkout a branch
docs.text:
• master: PR Base branch.
  • production: lastest release branch with distribution files. Never make a PR on this.
  • gh-pages: API docs, examples and demo

docs.title: Check code style
docs.text: Run the pylance extension and make sure all the tests pass.

docs.title: Test
docs.text: Run TODO and verify all the tests pass. If you are adding new commands or features, they must include tests. If you are changing functionality, update the tests if you need to.

docs.title: Commit
docs.text: Follow our commit message conventions.

docs.title: Yes! Pull request
docs.text: Make your pull request, then describe your changes.

docs.title: Title
docs.text:
Follow other PR title format on below.

    <Type>: Short Description (fix #111)
    <Type>: Short Description (fix #123, #111, #122)
    <Type>: Short Description (ref #111)
  • capitalize first letter of Type
  • use present tense: 'change' not 'changed' or 'changes'

docs.title: Description
docs.text: If it has related issues, add links to the issues(like #123) in the description. Fill in the Pull Request Template by check your case.

docs.title: For Developers
docs.text:
This is the homepage for all developer related documentation.

  • The API Guide, which aims to get you familiar with the APIs.
  • The Manual, which touches on models and functionality.
  • The System Architecture, shows system architecture.
  • The Data Model, shows database model design.

docs.title: API user guide
docs.text:
• Dataset API: this section explains the Dataset API guide for both GET and POST method.
  • Water Analysis API: this section explains the Analysis API guide for both GET and POST method.
  • Water Extent API: this section explains the Water Extent API guide for GET and POST methods.

docs.title: Water Analysis API
docs.text: These endpoints allow users to trigger water quality and quantity analysis over a specified time range and geographic region, and to query the status of the analysis task.

docs.title: Description
docs.text:
Triggers the execution of a water monitoring analysis using satellite imagery (e.g., Sentinel-2, Landsat) over a given time period and bounding box.

The task is executed asynchronously via Celery and results are stored under a unique task_uuid.

docs.title: Authentication
docs.text: Token / Basic / Session Requires login (IsAuthenticated)

docs.title: Request Body (JSON)
docs.text: Field Type Required Default Description start_date string ✅ Yes – ISO 8601 date (e.g., "2025-02-01") end_date string ✅ Yes – ISO 8601 date (e.g., "2025-02-28") bbox array ✅ Yes – Bounding box as [minX, minY, maxX, maxY] resolution int ❌ No 20 Spatial resolution in meters export_plot bool ❌ No true Whether to export a PNG plot export_nc bool ❌ No true Whether to export NetCDF export_cog bool ❌ No true Whether to export Cloud-Optimized GeoTIFFs calc_types list ❌ No ["AWEI", "NDCI", "NDTI", "SABI", "CDOM"] List of indicator types to calculate

docs.title: Example Request
docs.text:
{
  "start_date": "2025-02-01",
  "end_date": "2025-02-28",
  "bbox": [18.3, -34.1, 18.6, -33.9],
  "resolution": 10,
  "export_plot": true,
  "export_nc": false,
  "export_cog": true,
  "calc_types": ["AWEI", "NDCI"]
}

docs.title: Success Response
docs.text:
HTTP 200 OK 

{
  "message": {
    "task_uuid": "54c0a878-0be3-4db6-9289-15ff2ae2d239"
  }
}

docs.title: Error Responses
docs.text:
• 400 Bad Request – Missing required fields or invalid indicator type
  • 500 Internal Server Error – Task could not be launched

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Checks the status of a previously launched analysis task.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: • task_uuid (string): The unique identifier for the analysis task (UUID).

docs.title: Response
docs.text:
HTTP 200 OK 

{
  "uuid": "54c0a878-0be3-4db6-9289-15ff2ae2d239",
  "task_name": "Water Analysis demo_user",
  "status": "PENDING",
  "created_at": "2025-03-24T10:30:00Z",
  "result_files": {
    "awei": "https://.../awei_2025-02.tif",
    "ndci": "https://.../ndci_2025-02.nc"
  }
}

docs.title: Calculation Types Reference
docs.text: Indicator Description AWEI Automated Water Extraction Index – binary water mask NDCI Normalized Difference Chlorophyll Index – eutrophication marker NDTI Normalized Difference Turbidity Index – sediment level SABI Surface Algal Bloom Index – algal activity CDOM Colored Dissolved Organic Matter

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• If a task with identical parameters already exists, it will be returned instead of re-executed.
  • The task is executed in background using Celery; the client must poll the status endpoint.
  • Results will be stored and accessible from result_files in the task model once completed.

docs.title: Dataset API
docs.text: This endpoint provides an overview of all datasets stored in the SANSA Water Monitoring Platform. It supports filtering, pagination, and includes metadata summaries and dataset category counts.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Retrieves: - A paginated list of datasets - Count of datasets by category (DatasetType) - Creation date range (min_date, max_date)

docs.title: Authentication
docs.text:
• Required: Yes (Token, Session, or Basic)
  • Permission: IsAuthenticated

docs.title: Query Parameters
docs.text: Parameter Type Required Description dataset_type string No Filter datasets by category name page int No Pagination page number

docs.title: Response (Paginated)
docs.text:
{
  "count": 35,
  "next": "/api/datasets/?page=2",
  "previous": null,
  "results": {
    "total_entries": 35,
    "data_categories": [
      {"name": "Satellite", "count": 20},
      {"name": "In-Situ", "count": 15}
    ],
    "metadata": {
      "min_date": "2023-01-05T12:01:00Z",
      "max_date": "2025-03-26T09:47:00Z"
    },
    "datasets": [
      {
        "id": 1,
        "name": "Sentinel NDVI for Limpopo",
        "description": "Vegetation index dataset",
        "dataset_type": {
          "name": "Satellite",
          ...
        },
        "created_at": "...",
        ...
      }
    ]
  }
}

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• Efficient pagination with default page size: 10
  • Uses select_related for optimized DB queries
  • Dataset type aggregation using annotate(Count)
  • Summary stats using aggregate(Min, Max)

docs.title: Water Extent API
docs.text: These endpoints allow users to calculate water surface area (using the AWEI index) and generate binary water masks asynchronously. The system tracks task progress via Celery and provides outputs via task_uuid.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Triggers asynchronous calculation of water surface area (in km²) using satellite data (e.g., Landsat or Sentinel).

docs.title: Request Body
docs.text: Field Type Required Default Description bbox array ✅ Yes – Bounding box as [minX, minY, maxX, maxY] start_date string ✅ Yes – ISO 8601 date string end_date string ✅ Yes – ISO 8601 date string spatial_resolution int ❌ No 30 Resolution in meters input_type string ❌ No "Landsat" Either "Landsat" or "Sentinel"

docs.title: Response
docs.text:
HTTP 200 OK 

{
  "message": {
    "task_uuid": "c0a80124-19e4-11ee-be56-0242ac120002"
  }
}

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Checks the current status of the water extent calculation task and returns the result (if complete).

docs.title: Response
docs.text:
HTTP 200 OK 

{
    "uuid": "c0a80124-19e4-11ee-be56-0242ac120002",
    "task_name": "Water Extent - admin",
    "status": "SUCCESS",
    "parameters": {
        ...
    },
    "started_at": "2025-03-25T11:57:08.611605Z",
    "completed_at": "2025-03-25T11:57:08.694063Z",
    "created_at": "2025-03-25T11:57:08.476018Z",
    "task_outputs": [],
    "area_km2": 47.07
}

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Triggers asynchronous generation of a water mask using the AWEI index.

docs.title: Request Body
docs.text: Field Type Required Default Description bbox array ✅ Yes – Bounding box as [minX, minY, maxX, maxY] spatial_resolution int ❌ No 10 Resolution in meters input_type string ❌ No "Sentinel" Either "Landsat" or "Sentinel"

docs.title: Response
docs.text:

    "task_uuid": "b4cccd20-3452-11ee-b8c2-0242ac120002"

            "size": 24918,
            "monitoring_type": "AWEI_MASK",
            "created_at": "2025-03-25T23:50:27.701142Z"

docs.text:

  • Use task_uuid to track results and download files after processing is complete.

docs.title: Development Guide: project App
docs.text: This guide explains how to work within the project Django app. It provides a quick reference for adding views, tasks, serializers, and utilities that power the Water Quantity and Quality Monitoring Platform.

docs.title: App Directory Structure
docs.text: Folder Purpose api_views/ Contains Django REST Framework API views models/ Django ORM models (e.g., AnalysisTask, TaskOutput) serializers/ Transforms models to/from JSON for the API tasks/ Background processing tasks (via Celery) utils/ Custom logic for analysis, masking, etc.

docs.title: API Views
docs.text:
Add views to api_views/, typically subclassing APIView.

Example: Creating a view that triggers an analysis.

from rest_framework.views import APIView
from rest_framework.response import Response
from rest_framework.permissions import IsAuthenticated
from project.tasks.analysis import run_analysis

class WaterAnalysisAPIView(APIView):
    permission_classes = [IsAuthenticated]

    def post(self, request):
        data = request.data
        result = run_analysis.delay(
            start_date=data.get("start_date"),
            end_date=data.get("end_date"),
            bbox=data.get("bbox"),
            task_id="..."
        )
        return Response({"task_id": result.id})

Register it in urls.py:

from .api_views import example

urlpatterns = [
    path("api/example/", example.ExampleView.as_view()),
]

docs.title: Celery Tasks
docs.text:
Tasks in tasks/ perform long-running or scheduled background jobs.

Example: run_analysis task

@app.task(bind=True, name='run_analysis')
def run_analysis(self, start_date, end_date, bbox, ...):
    ...
  • Updates task state
  • Calls Analysis.run()
  • Logs progress and results to AnalysisTask

Use .delay() to enqueue:

run_analysis.delay(start_date="2025-02-01", end_date="2025-02-28", ...)

docs.title: Serializers
docs.text:
Serializers live in serializers/. They define how model instances are converted to API-friendly data and vice versa.

Example: Serialize TaskOutput with a full file URL.

class TaskOutputSerializer(serializers.ModelSerializer):
    file = serializers.SerializerMethodField()

    def get_file(self, obj):
        return self.context['request'].build_absolute_uri(obj.file.url)

    class Meta:
        model = TaskOutput
        fields = ['id', 'file', 'size', 'monitoring_type']

Use SerializerMethodField for custom logic like building absolute URLs or mapping model properties.

docs.title: Utility Functions
docs.text:
Utility logic for calculations and processing resides in utils/.

Common file locations: - utils/calculations/analysis.py — wraps index computation and water mask generation - utils/calculations/extract_info.py — info parsing helpers - utils/calculations/monitoring.py — utilities for reporting or evaluation

Example usage:

from project.utils.calculations.analysis import Analysis

result = Analysis(...).run()

docs.title: Testing
docs.text:
• Add tests in project/tests/
  • Use Django’s test runner
  • Test views, tasks, and logic with representative inputs

docs.title: Related Docs
docs.text:
• API Reference – Water Analysis
  • Django REST Framework
  • Celery Task Docs

docs.title: Core Module Overview
docs.text: The core module contains the foundational configuration of the SANSA Water Monitoring Platform. It includes the project’s execution entrypoints, background task framework, project-wide settings, URL routing, and context processors.

docs.title: Contents
docs.text: File / Directory Description asgi.py ASGI entrypoint for asynchronous deployments (e.g. Uvicorn, Daphne). wsgi.py WSGI entrypoint used by traditional servers (e.g. Gunicorn, uWSGI). celery.py Initializes Celery workers and integrates with Django settings and django-celery-beat. context_processors.py Custom Django context processors (e.g., exposing Sentry DSN to templates). factories.py Defines test data factories (e.g., UserFactory) for unit testing. urls.py Project-level URL router: connects to API and admin paths. settings/ (directory) Contains all Django settings (e.g., base, dev, prod configs). Should include base.py, local.py, etc.

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text:
The core app is not a functional app but the backbone of the Django project. It:

  • Manages how the server runs (asgi, wsgi)
  • Coordinates background tasks (celery)
  • Controls environment-specific configuration (settings/)
  • Links your API and admin through URLs
  • Defines reusable behaviors like template context injection

docs.title: Celery Configuration (core/celery.py)
docs.text: This module sets up the Celery worker for the SANSA Water Monitoring Platform. Celery is used for asynchronous task execution and scheduled background jobs such as satellite analysis and data ingestion.

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text:
The celery.py file configures:

  • Redis as the Celery broker
  • Integration with Django settings
  • Automatic task discovery from all registered apps
  • Django admin support for periodic tasks via django-celery-beat

docs.title: 1. Set Django Settings
docs.text:
os.environ.setdefault('DJANGO_SETTINGS_MODULE', 'core.settings')
Ensures that the Django environment is loaded before Celery starts.

docs.title: 2. Broker URL Configuration
docs.text:
BASE_REDIS_URL = (
    f'redis://default:{os.environ.get("REDIS_PASSWORD", "")}'
    f'@{os.environ.get("REDIS_HOST", "")}',
)
  • Uses environment variables to build the Redis broker URL.
  • Expected variables:
  • REDIS_HOST: Redis server hostname
  • REDIS_PASSWORD: (optional) password

docs.title: 3. Celery App Initialization
docs.text:
app = Celery('sansa-water-quality-and-quantity')
The name here matches the project identifier used across tasks.

docs.title: 4. Settings Integration
docs.text:
app.config_from_object('django.conf:settings', namespace='CELERY')
This allows you to define Celery settings in settings.py using the CELERY_ prefix.

Example: 

CELERY_TIMEZONE = 'Africa/Johannesburg'
CELERY_TASK_TRACK_STARTED = True

docs.title: 5. Task Autodiscovery
docs.text:
app.autodiscover_tasks()
Finds all modules named tasks.py in installed apps.

docs.title: 6. Beat Scheduler
docs.text:
app.conf.beat_scheduler = 'django_celery_beat.schedulers.DatabaseScheduler'
This enables recurring tasks to be managed in the Django admin via django-celery-beat.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
Start the worker: 

celery -A core worker -l info

Start the scheduler (for beat): 

celery -A core beat -l info

docs.title: Related Tools
docs.text:
• Django-Celery-Beat
  • Celery Documentation

docs.title: context_processors.py
docs.text: This file defines a single context processor used to inject settings into template context.

docs.title: sentry_dsn
docs.text:
def sentry_dsn(request):
    return {
        'SENTRY_DSN': settings.SENTRY_DSN
    }

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
Add it to your TEMPLATES settings:

'OPTIONS': {
    'context_processors': [
        ...,
        'core.context_processors.sentry_dsn',
    ]
}

docs.title: Factory: UserFactory
docs.text: This file defines a test data factory using the factory_boy library for quickly generating User model instances in tests.

docs.title: UserFactory
docs.text:
class UserFactory(factory.django.DjangoModelFactory):
    class Meta:
        model = get_user_model()

    username = factory.Sequence(lambda n: f"user{n}")
    password = factory.PostGenerationMethodCall('set_password', 'password123')

docs.title: Details
docs.text:
• Base: DjangoModelFactory from factory_boy
  • Model: Dynamically resolves to Django’s current user model
  • Fields:
  • username: Auto-incrementing usernames (e.g., user0, user1, ...)
  • password: Uses Django's set_password() to hash password123

docs.title: Use Case
docs.text:
This factory is used in unit or integration tests to easily create user accounts.

user = UserFactory()
assert user.check_password("password123")

No need to manually create or clean up users in test setups.

docs.title: URL Configuration (core/urls.py)
docs.text: This file defines the root URL configuration for the SANSA Water Monitoring Platform project. It connects app-specific routes and Django’s admin interface.

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text: The urlpatterns list maps top-level URL patterns to views and app-level routers. It also conditionally serves media files in development mode.

docs.title: Main Patterns
docs.text:
urlpatterns = [
    path('api/', include('project.urls')),
    path('', admin.site.urls),
]
  • api/: Routes all API endpoints defined in project/urls.py
  • /: Maps the root URL to the Django admin dashboard

docs.title: Static/Media Files (Development Only)
docs.text:
if settings.DEBUG:
    urlpatterns += static(
        settings.MEDIA_URL, document_root=settings.MEDIA_ROOT)
  • Allows serving uploaded files (e.g., GeoTIFFs, NetCDF) via the development server
  • Not used in production (where a web server or CDN should serve media)

docs.title: Example Result
docs.text:
• http://localhost:8000/ → Django admin
  • http://localhost:8000/api/monitoring/ → Project API endpoint (if defined)
  • http://localhost:8000/media/output_file.tif → Served during development

docs.title: Related Docs
docs.text: • project/urls.py: Defines the API and internal routes for the application

docs.title: Admin Interface Documentation
docs.text: The Django Admin module provides an interface for managing datasets, data providers, monitoring tasks, logs, and external sources in the SANSA Water Monitoring Platform. This document outlines how each model is represented, filtered, and managed in the admin dashboard.

docs.title: DatasetTypeAdmin
docs.text:
Manages classification of dataset types, such as Satellite or In-Situ.

  • Fields Displayed: id, name
  • Search: By name
  • Use Case: Helps users define new dataset categories or rename existing ones.

docs.title: DatasetAdmin
docs.text:
Controls access to structured datasets that are linked to ingestion and analysis pipelines.

  • Fields Displayed: id, name, dataset_type, created_at, updated_at
  • Search: Dataset name
  • Filters:
  • Dataset type
  • Creation and update dates

docs.title: ExternalDataSourceAdmin
docs.text:
Allows configuring dynamic data sources such as REST APIs that ingest water or environmental data.

  • Fieldsets:
  • General Information: name, description
  • API Configuration (collapsible):
    • URL, auth requirements, token, request method (GET/POST), response format (JSON, XML, GeoTIFF, etc.), and additional parameters
  • Display: id, name, api_url, requires_auth, created_at
  • Searchable: By name or URL
  • Filter: requires_auth

docs.title: APIUsageLogAdmin
docs.text:
Tracks usage of backend APIs by authenticated users.

  • Fields: user, endpoint, method, status_code, requested_at
  • Searchable: Endpoint
  • Filterable: Method type and date

docs.title: DataIngestionLogAdmin
docs.text:
Keeps records of all data ingestion attempts — successful or failed.

  • Fields: API call, file ingested, time of fetch, status, and optional message
  • Search: Filename or message
  • Filters: Ingestion status, date

docs.title: ErrorLogAdmin
docs.text:
Displays captured application-level errors.

  • Fields: Associated API/task, module name, error type/message, and timestamp
  • Filter: Error type, date

docs.title: UserActivityLogAdmin
docs.text:
Audits user actions such as login, logout, data download, etc.

  • Fields: User, action type, timestamp
  • Search: Username
  • Filter: Action type, date

docs.title: TaskLogAdmin
docs.text:
Generic logger tied to any model object using Django’s content type framework.

  • Fields: Log message, log level, linked object, and timestamp
  • Search: UUID or log message
  • Filters: Content type, severity, date

docs.title: MonitoringIndicatorTypeAdmin
docs.text:
Manages types of indicators such as: - AWEI (surface water) - NDCI (chlorophyll) - NDTI (turbidity) - SABI, CDOM

  • Fields: Name, description, indicator type enum
  • Filters: Indicator type

docs.title: MonitoringIndicatorAdmin
docs.text:
View actual computed values from STAC analysis.

  • Fields: Linked dataset, indicator type, value, timestamp
  • Filters: Type, date
  • Search: Indicator name

docs.title: MonitoringReportAdmin
docs.text:
View/download full reports created from indicators.

  • Fields: Linked user, indicator, description, time, and download URL
  • Search: Description, date

docs.title: ScheduledTaskAdmin
docs.text:
Defines recurring tasks like ingestion or batch analysis.

  • Fields: Task ID, name, status, start and end time
  • Filter: Status, date

docs.title: AnalysisTaskAdmin
docs.text:
Admin for analysis jobs triggered via API or UI.

  • Fields: Task name, status, creator, creation/start/end timestamps
  • Filters: Status, time
  • Inline: Related TaskOutput files
  • Read-Only Fields: UUID and timestamps
  • Ordering: Newest first

docs.title: TaskOutputAdmin
docs.text:
Access output files such as GeoTIFFs, NetCDFs, PNGs.

  • Fields: File path, indicator type, task, creator, timestamp
  • Filters: Indicator type, user
  • Search: Task name, indicator, username

docs.title: ProviderAdmin
docs.text:
Manages external organizations or systems that supply datasets.

  • Fields: Name, created/updated timestamp
  • Searchable: Provider name

docs.title: DataSourceFileAdmin
docs.text:
Track individual raw data files linked to a dataset and provider.

  • Fields: Name, associated dataset, provider, upload time
  • Searchable: Filename or timestamp

docs.title: Model Documentation: Core Data Models
docs.text: This page documents all the key database models in the SANSA Water Quantity and Quality Monitoring Platform. Each model reflects a table in the PostgreSQL database and plays a critical role in data ingestion, processing, analysis, reporting, or auditing.

docs.title: DatasetType (project_datasettype)
docs.text:
Classifies datasets by origin:

  • name: Display label for the type.
  • description: Optional explanation.
  • dataset_type: Enum - either "satellite" or "in-situ".

Used to group datasets for analytics and interface filtering.

docs.title: Dataset (project_dataset)
docs.text:
Structured dataset derived from raw files or external sources.

  • name: Label for dataset.
  • description: Optional context.
  • dataset_type: Foreign key to DatasetType.
  • created_at / updated_at: Timestamps for tracking data lineage.

docs.title: ExternalDataSource (project_externaldatasource)
docs.text:
Defines API endpoints for dynamic ingestion.

  • name: Source name (e.g., OpenWeather API).
  • api_url: Full URL to API.
  • requires_auth: Boolean flag.
  • auth_token: Used if auth is required.
  • request_method: GET or POST.
  • response_format: One of JSON, XML, CSV, GeoTIFF.
  • additional_params: Optional request params (JSON).

Enables plug-and-play external integrations.

docs.title: Provider (project_provider)
docs.text:
Organization or system providing raw data.

  • name: Provider name.
  • description: Optional notes.

docs.title: DataSourceFile (project_datasourcefile)
docs.text:
Represents a raw file received from a provider.

  • dataset: Dataset this file supports.
  • provider: Who sent the file.
  • uploaded_at: Timestamp for when it was added.

docs.title: MonitoringIndicatorType (project_monitoringindicatortype)
docs.text:
Enum list of monitoring types:

  • AWEI, NDCI, NDTI, SABI, CDOM.
  • monitoring_indicator_type: Stores enum value.
  • name / description: Display metadata.

docs.title: MonitoringIndicator (project_monitoringindicator)
docs.text:
Computed value for a dataset.

  • dataset: What dataset was used.
  • monitoring_indicator_type: What was calculated.
  • value: Float value.
  • generated_at: Time of computation.

docs.title: MonitoringReport (project_monitoringreport)
docs.text:
Downloadable or link-based report from indicator computation.

  • user: Creator.
  • monitoring_indicator: What this report is based on.
  • report_link: Direct URL to report file.

docs.title: ScheduledTask (project_scheduledtask)
docs.text:
Background jobs triggered on a schedule.

  • uuid: Unique ID.
  • status: pending, running, completed, failed.
  • started_at / completed_at: Timestamps for lifecycle.

docs.title: AnalysisTask (project_analysistask)
docs.text:
User-triggered analysis operation.

  • parameters: JSON object with bbox, date, etc.
  • created_by: Who triggered it.
  • celery_task_id: Links to Celery worker task.
  • Status helpers: .start(), .complete(), .failed(), .add_log().

docs.title: TaskOutput (project_taskoutput)
docs.text:
Generated file from an analysis task.

  • file: Output file path (GeoTIFF, NetCDF, etc).
  • monitoring_type: What kind of data it contains.
  • size: Bytes.
  • created_by: Uploader/creator.

docs.title: APIUsageLog (project_apiusagelog)
docs.text:
Track every API call:

  • user: Who made the call.
  • endpoint: Path accessed.
  • method: GET, POST, PUT, DELETE.
  • status_code: HTTP status.
  • requested_at: Timestamp.

docs.title: DataIngestionLog (project_dataingestionlog)
docs.text:
Track outcomes of fetch attempts.

  • api_log: Associated request.
  • data_source_file: What was fetched.
  • status: success or failed.
  • message: Optional result or error message.

docs.title: ErrorLog (project_errorlog)
docs.text:
Captured exception or crash event.

  • api_log / task: Context of failure.
  • module_name: Source module.
  • error_type: Type name (e.g., ValueError).
  • error_message: Description.
  • occured_at: Timestamp.

docs.title: TaskLog (project_tasklog)
docs.text:
Stores structured logs using Django’s GenericForeignKey.

  • log: Text.
  • level: Logging level (int).
  • content_type: Linked model.
  • object_id: UUID or ID of instance.

docs.title: UserActivityLog (project_useractivitylog)
docs.text:
Audit trail of user actions.

  • user: Who acted.
  • activity_type: LOGIN, LOGOUT, DOWNLOAD, etc.
  • timestamp: When it occurred.

docs.title: Serializer Documentation
docs.text: This section describes the Django REST Framework serializers used in the SANSA Water Monitoring Platform. Serializers convert model instances into JSON representations and vice versa, and handle validation for incoming API requests.

docs.title: DatasetTypeSerializer
docs.text: A basic serializer for the DatasetType model.

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text:
• Used to serialize and expose dataset classification types (e.g., Satellite, In-Situ).
  • Automatically includes all fields from the model.
class DatasetTypeSerializer(serializers.ModelSerializer):
    class Meta:
        model = DatasetType
        fields = "__all__"

docs.title: DatasetSerializer
docs.text:
Serializer for the Dataset model. It includes a nested DatasetTypeSerializer for full representation of the dataset type.

class DatasetSerializer(serializers.ModelSerializer):
    dataset_type = DatasetTypeSerializer()

    class Meta:
        model = Dataset
        fields = "__all__"

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• The dataset_type is fully expanded instead of just showing the foreign key ID.
  • Ideal for read-only views or admin APIs.

docs.title: TaskOutputSerializer
docs.text: Serializes the outputs of an analysis task, including the file URL and its indicator type.

docs.title: Custom Fields
docs.text:
• file: Absolute URL of the output file, built from the request context.
  • monitoring_type: Extracted display name of the indicator type.
class TaskOutputSerializer(serializers.ModelSerializer):
    file = serializers.SerializerMethodField()
    monitoring_type = serializers.SerializerMethodField()

    def get_file(self, obj):
        request = self.context.get('request')
        if request is not None:
            return request.build_absolute_uri(obj.file.url)
        return obj.file.url

    def get_monitoring_type(self, obj):
        return obj.monitoring_type.monitoring_indicator_type

    class Meta:
        model = TaskOutput
        fields = ['id', 'file', 'size', 'monitoring_type', 'created_at']

docs.title: AnalysisTaskStatusSerializer
docs.text:
Provides a full summary of a background analysis task, including related outputs.

  • Includes all relevant metadata: task ID, name, status, timestamps, parameters
  • Nested field task_outputs lists generated result files
class AnalysisTaskStatusSerializer(serializers.ModelSerializer):
    task_outputs = TaskOutputSerializer(many=True, read_only=True)

    class Meta:
        model = AnalysisTask
        fields = ['uuid', 'task_name', 'status', 'parameters', 'started_at', 'completed_at', 'created_at', 'task_outputs']

docs.title: Task Documentation
docs.text: This section describes the Celery tasks used in the SANSA Water Quantity and Quality Monitoring Platform. Tasks enable long-running or resource-intensive operations to run asynchronously in the background.

docs.title: run_analysis
docs.text: Launches a complete multi-index water analysis process.

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Triggers analysis based on user-specified parameters such as start/end date, bounding box, resolution, and indicator types (e.g., AWEI, NDCI).

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text:
• start_date, end_date: ISO date strings
  • bbox: List of bounding box coordinates
  • resolution: Output resolution in meters (default: 20)
  • export_plot, export_nc, export_cog: Toggles for optional outputs
  • calc_types: List of monitoring indices to calculate
  • task_id: UUID of the corresponding AnalysisTask

docs.title: update_stored_data
docs.text: Placeholder task for updating stored data. - Currently logs that the update operation was triggered. - To be implemented with a data crawling routine in the future.

docs.title: compute_water_extent_task
docs.text: Calculates the surface area (in km²) of water bodies from a previously generated AWEI raster.

docs.title: Description
docs.text:
• Loads the latest AWEI output from a given task
  • Applies a threshold and computes area using raster utils
  • Adds area log to the task and updates task status

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text:
• task_id: UUID of the associated task
  • bbox, spatial_resolution, input_type, start_date, end_date: Task metadata
  • threshold: AWEI threshold to distinguish water vs non-water

docs.title: Returns
docs.text:
{
  "area_km2": 73.21,
  "task_id": "...",
  "threshold": 0.0
}

docs.title: generate_water_mask_task
docs.text: Creates a binary water mask raster from a task's AWEI output.

docs.title: Description
docs.text:
• Loads the AWEI GeoTIFF file
  • Applies a threshold to generate binary mask
  • Saves the mask as a new TaskOutput file
  • Logs completion to AnalysisTask

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Same as compute_water_extent_task

docs.title: Returns
docs.text:
{
  "mask_url": "https://.../mask.tif",
  "task_id": "...",
  ...
}

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• All tasks use self.update_state() to report progress.
  • Exceptions are caught and logged to TaskLog.
  • Each task references AnalysisTask for tracking.

These tasks are launched using .delay(...) from views or admin panels and are critical to automated water monitoring pipelines.

docs.title: Utility Functions and Analysis Classes
docs.text: This section documents the core utility classes and functions powering satellite-based water monitoring and pollution assessment in the SANSA platform. These tools cover everything from data ingestion to raster processing, statistical reporting, and pollution analysis.

docs.title: Analysis Class
docs.text: Used by Celery tasks to process Sentinel-2 imagery via STAC and compute monthly indicators.

docs.title: Key Features:
docs.text:
• Loads imagery from AWS Earth Search (via STAC)
  • Computes water-related indices: AWEI, NDCI, NDTI, SABI, CDOM
  • Outputs results in multiple formats (COG, NetCDF, PNG)
  • Writes logs and uploads files to TaskOutput

docs.title: Parameters:
docs.text:
• bbox: Geographic bounds
  • start_date / end_date: Time window
  • resolution: Spatial resolution in meters
  • calc_types: Index types to compute (optional)
  • task: Reference to AnalysisTask for logging/output saving

docs.title: CalculateMonitoring Class
docs.text:
A streamlined version of Analysis used for non-Celery batch runs or debugging. It prints outputs directly to console and doesn’t integrate with the Django task model.

Same calculation and export logic as Analysis, but decoupled from the Django task system.

docs.title: calculate_indices(image_path, bands, output_dir)
docs.text: A raster-based implementation that computes four remote sensing indices from raw Sentinel-2 bands.

docs.title: Output Indices:
docs.text:
• AWEI_sh: For shadow removal
  • AWEI_ns: For general water detection
  • NDTI: Turbidity proxy
  • NDCI: Chlorophyll-related metric

docs.title: Notes:
docs.text:
• Reads/writes block-by-block using window iteration
  • Optimized for large TIFFs

docs.title: calculate_water_extent_from_tif(tif_path, threshold=0.0)
docs.text: Calculates surface water area from AWEI raster output. Uses a pixel-wise threshold and multiplies by pixel area to get total km².

docs.title: Returns:
docs.text:
• Surface area
  • Geo-metadata (CRS, width, height)

Used in: compute_water_extent_task

docs.title: generate_water_mask_from_tif(...)
docs.text: Generates a binary water mask from an AWEI GeoTIFF by applying a threshold. Optimized to handle large raster files using chunked windows.

docs.title: Output:
docs.text:
• New mask TIFF file path
  • Metadata: resolution, CRS, threshold used

Used in: generate_water_mask_task

docs.title: extract_tiff_info(image_path)
docs.text:
Extracts metadata and statistics from multi-band TIFFs: - Band-wise min, max, mean, std_dev - Histogram counts - No-data pixel count - Raster metadata (size, resolution, CRS)

Outputs are JSON-ready and ideal for audit dashboards.

docs.title: PollutionAnalyzer Class
docs.text: Used to assess pollution intensity based on raster index values (NDTI and NDCI) over known source locations (factories, farms).

docs.title: Inputs:
docs.text:
• Point and polygon shapefiles
  • Corresponding index rasters (NDTI/NDCI)

docs.title: Outputs:
docs.text:
• JSON reports with mean index per geometry
  • Logs for skipped geometries

docs.title: Use Case:
docs.text:
• Water pollution attribution
  • Hotspot identification
  • Risk mapping
